title: 114_hr3855
content: The "Taxpayer Receipt Act" is cited as the short title. It introduces an itemized federal tax receipt in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Taxpayer Receipt Act requires the Secretary to send taxpayers an itemized Federal tax receipt showing how their tax payment is allocated among major expenditure categories. It also includes information on Federal debt and additional borrowing per legal United States resident. Total tax payment is the sum of taxes imposed by subtitle A and section 3101 on wages received. The Taxpayer Receipt Act mandates the Secretary to provide taxpayers with a detailed breakdown of how their tax payment is divided among major expenditure categories. The allocation is determined by the percentage of Federal outlays for categories like Social Security, National defense, Medicare, Low-income assistance programs, and Other Federal health programs. The curr_chunk provides a breakdown of federal spending in various categories including Medicaid, health research, regulatory activities, unemployment benefits, veterans benefits, education, federal employee benefits, transportation funding, and mortgage finance. The curr_chunk outlines federal spending on mortgage finance, justice and law enforcement, natural resources, foreign aid, science and technology research, air transportation, farm subsidies, and energy funding. The curr_chunk lists various major expenditure categories including disaster relief, diplomacy, environmental protection, IRS operations, Coast Guard programs, and Congress activities. The curr_chunk discusses the timing and use of Federal tax receipts, encouraging the IRS to utilize modern technologies for distribution without charging taxpayers. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for this section. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section regarding the Federal tax receipt will apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act.
